e4: As a board member, I recommend changing to the new policy. Although the current consistent over-reporting might stabilize stock prices and protect investor relations in certain periods due to informed adjustments by the market community, the practice poses long-term legal and ethical liabilities. New investors who may be unaware of existing practices will require full information transparency along with the market fairness guaranteed through unbiased reporting. In essence, a credible company stands for truthful and objective finance to maintain long-term sustainability.
e5: In the context given, a reporting policy must maintain transparency by reflecting true and actual unbiased earnings without any deception or intentionally misleading investors for ulterior purposes such as capital raising. An ethical EPS report should: 1) adhere to high professional standards that abide by existing regulations and avoid potential legal liabilities, like SEC investigations; 2) empower responsible shareholders to make informed decisions while mitigating the risk disparities between retail investors versus institutional investors (such as hedge funds); 3) provide reliable financial statements without adjustment by any involved community members or third-party market intermediaries in expectation of maintaining fairness, equity, and justice in transactions; 4) enable effective communication that clearly demonstrates, to all potential stakeholders, a commitment to transparency through periodic updates and regular updates.
e6: In light of the concerns shared by the CFO regarding existing investors' assumptions about adjusted EPS as well as potential disadvantages for retail shareholders due to sophisticated hedge funds' knowledge, I would explore the following: 1) Have any changes in investor profile or market position warranting reconsideration of the reporting policy in view of increased transparency concerns? 2) If investors are making adjustments on their own, is education required regarding reported EPS without bias and potential adverse effects under old/current practice on investor confidence long-term? 3) Can investor retention strategies be devised that encourage retail participation over an extended time frame under a new reporting policy to foster investor cohesion and loyalty?
